results.title: David Livingston
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Rank, Gaumont-British Instructional, Frank Wells and David Middlemas
results.brief_description: Outlines the early days of David Livingston(e) in Africa and the series of journeys throughout the continent extending over a period of 30 years. The film illustrates particularly the importance of Livington’s exploration and actual scenes show the nature of the country through which he made his journeys. Tribute is paid to his work in combating the slave trade. The film ends with a reconstruction of this meeting with Stanley and an artist’s impression of his death and the final journey of his body to the coast and to Westminster Abbey.

results.title: David Lean: a self portrait
results.creator_credit: Thomas Craven Film Corporation and Thomas Craven
results.brief_description: A comprehensive documentary made in collaboration with the noted director at work on the set, on location, and in the editing room, as he explains his viewpoint about the film and his method of work. Illustrates with excerpt from several of Lean’s films, which together have won a number of awards. Includes interviews with Sam Spiegel who produced some of Lean’s early films and Robert Bolt who wrote the scripts for Lean’s last three films.

results.title: David Kennedy [ALP Member for Bendigo]
results.brief_description: Campaign film for ALP Member for Bendigo, David Kennedy. Features footage of Kennedy campaigning in the streets of Bendigo with Gough Whitlam and being interviewed about his views on Bendigo and his family. Issues of concern to the community are raised such as postal services, state of the education system, and loss of youth to the bigger cities. Also desire for a National Health Scheme and concern for wheat farmers. Features good shots of historical interest of Bendigo in the early 1970s. Script by Bill Hartley.

results.title: David Copperfield
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, David O. Selznick and George Cukor
results.brief_description: David Copperfield enjoys an idyllic life with his gentle mother and his loving nurse, Peggotty. Tragedy strikes when Mr Murdstone, a monster of cruelty, weds David’s mother and drives her to an early grave. His adventures from this time introduce us to every stratum of colourful Victorian society. Since its debut in 1935, “David Copperfield” has been acclaimed for its handpicked cast, one that remains unsurpassed to this day. Stars W.C. Fields, Maureen O’Sullivan, Lionel Barrymore, Freddie Bartholomew, May Oliver, Basil Rathbone and over 65 star cast players. Based on the novel by Charles Dickens. Rated: G

results.title: David Copperfield
results.creator_credit: BBC, Kate Harwood and Simon Curtis
results.brief_description: Charles Dicken’s classic tale of the boy whose life is changed irrevocable when his mother marries the cruel Mr Murdstone, only to die and leave her son in his sinister clutches is brought to life in this BBC production which includes a stellar cast of Bob Hoskins, Maggie Smith, Betsey Trotwood, Trevor Eve, Nicholas Lyndhurst, Pauline Quirke, Ian Holm and Ciaran McMenamin as David.

results.title: David Carradine's Tai Chi Workout
results.brief_description: Perfected centuries ago, Tai Chi remains one of the most efficient forms of exercise ever developed. Unlike most of today’s exercises, it actually increases your mental and physical energy through systematic stress reduction. Guided by David Carradine (star of television’s “Kung Fu”) you will learn graceful flowing movements which tone muscles, firm the body and enhance flexibility.

results.title: David Bowie: serious moonlight
results.creator_credit: Concert Productions International, Anthony Eaton and David Mallet
results.brief_description: Filmed live performance of David Bowie on his 1983 Serious Moonlight World Tour at the P.N.E. Grandstand, Vancouver, British Columbia. Highly regarded and world renowned rock performer/entertainer, David Bowie sings his way through some of his most popular classics.

results.title: David Bowie is becoming a Medium
results.brief_description: Speaking to the BBC in 1976, Bowie claimed that his career was built on the desire to “be the instigator of new ideas….to turn people on to new things and new perspectives…to be that sort of catalytic kind of thing.“ He described rock music as a medium through which he could achieve this impact and speculated that he would move from using rock in this way to becoming a medium himself, saying, “hopefully that’ll happen one day…that’s really why I do it…to become a medium.” This talk takes Bowie’s characteristically self-aware and oblique statement as a starting point for an exploration of his extraordinary creative impact and cultural status. Sharing insights gained during the making of ‘David Bowie is’ at the V&A, it explains how the exhibition was devised to perpetuate the catalytic and inspirational power of Bowie’s art, style and music. Presented by Dr Kathryn Johnson, Assistant Curator for the ‘David Bowie is’ Exhibition from the V&A Museum.

results.title: David Anderson: works on film
results.creator_credit: Redwing, Barnaby Spurrier, James Bradley, David Anderson and David Jeffcock
results.brief_description: David Anderson is one of the Uk’s leading animators, and in this collection his creative and technical range is given full rein. The program begins with Anderson’s BAFTA Award-winning debut film “Dreamland express” (1982) which captures the rich fantasy life of childhood. “Sweet disaster, dreamless sleep” (1986) is a poignant allegory on the theme of the nuclear nightmare. “Deadtime stories for big folk” is the title of a collaboration between Anderson and the novelist Russell Hoban, and a documentary on this includes the full versions of the two films involved, “Deadsy” (1989) and “Door” (1990). Both have won many awards and are powerful and disturbing pieces.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Redwing, Barnaby Spurrier, James Bradley, David Anderson and David Jeffcock

results.title: David and Hazel: a story in communication
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Nicholas Balla and John Howe
results.brief_description: A study of what may happen when a husband insulates his job from his family. David believes that what happens at work is his sole concern. Hazel has grown to accept her husband’s estimation of himself as a breadwinner and of herself as homemaker, and does not expect his confidences when things go wrong. A neighbour voices quite different views about the sharing of family problems. When David’s job is threatened, it is from this neighbour that Hazel hears of it. Her worries, added to David’s, trigger a chain of reaction of bruised feelings. Presented as a case study for discussion on family relations.
